div.bibl: Chicago Greek Daily, March , 1930AN OPINION ON THE COMMERCIAL PROGRESS OF HELLENISM IN AMERICA

body.p: p. 6.- I have visited the pie factory of the Greek corporation, Chicago Pie Co., at West 24th and Congress Streets. The Chicago Pie Company owns the factory building whose architecture is modern and equipped up-to-date with the latest models in machinery. It is one of the best bakeries of its kind, in which about 100 men and women work.
Mr. Karalis, having showed me the plant, started giving me his opinion of Greeks in America.
"I will tell you something," he said, "that may seem to you a dream. But, let us not forget that if it were not for dreams there could not be any realities."

Mr. Karalis continued, "What we Greeks ought to do in America is to organize a Chamber of Commerce, with headquarters in Chicago, at the center of the country, to regulate things concerning the commerce and progress, generally, of Hellenism. We must cooperate and organize, in order to fight the

syndicates or else, poor and singled out as we are, we cannot exist commercially. We must remember that we live in a country where everything is managed and directed by scientific systems, which we must acquire if we are to elevate ourselves socially and economically. This qualification will be supplied by study because the Greek is naturally diligent."

This is what Mr. Karalis said and added: "We are satisfied that the majority of the Greeks support us. Most of the minority deal with concerns which are run by people of nationalities other than Greek. We do not resent this because we realize that it is necessary to deal with these others on account of business interests.
